Introduction

Dacryocystitis is an inflammatory condition of the lacrimal sac caused by obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct.  It results in the accumulation and stagnation of tears within the lacrimal sac, which promote infection and inflammation.  Symptoms include tenderness, erythema, and edema over the inferior medial canthus; purulent discharge may be expressed from the eyelid puncta.  Treatment of acute infection involves warm compresses, lacrimal sac massage, and antibiotics.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



The lacrimal system is responsible for draining tears from the eye into the nasal cavity (

figure 1
).  Dacryocystitis occurs when the nasolacrimal duct becomes obstructed and tears back up into the lacrimal sac.  Stagnation of fluid within the sac creates an environment conducive to bacterial growth.  Common pathogens implicated in dacryocystitis include Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.



Several factors increase the risk for lacrimal gland obstruction and dacryocystitis, including:



  • Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction (dacryostenosis)
  • Aging (may cause narrowing of the puncta)
  • History of trauma to the face or nose (eg, nasoethmoid fracture)
  • Previous endonasal or endoscopic sinus surgery
  • Chronic rhinosinusitis

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation of dacryocystitis may include (

image 1
):



  • Pain, erythema, swelling, and tenderness over the lacrimal sac/medial canthus
  • Mucopurulent discharge from the puncta
  • Excessive tearing (epiphora)
  • Fever and systemic symptoms (in severe cases)

Diagnosis



Dacryocystitis is typically a clinical diagnosis made primarily on history and physical examination findings.  Gram stain and culture of purulent discharge may be helpful for narrowing antibiotic coverage.  If there are signs of systemic toxicity (eg, fever), a complete blood count and blood cultures are also recommended.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis of dacryocystitis includes (

):



  • Blepharitis (
    image 2
    ):  inflammation of the eyelid margin.  Patients typically have erythema and swelling of the eyelid margin with crusting of the eyelashes.  It does not cause focal tenderness over the lacrimal sac.
  • Chalazion (
    image 3
    ):  a chronic granulomatous lesion of the meibomian gland that appears as a painless, firm nodule deep to the eyelid margin.  Unlike dacryocystitis, chalazia are not associated with tearing, discharge, or tenderness.
  • Hordeolum (stye) (
    image 4
    ):  an acute, focal infection of the eyelid.  Hordeola typically present as discrete, tender nodules at the eyelid margin; localized swelling and erythema often develop, but typically do not extend into the medial canthal region.
  • Preseptal (periorbital) cellulitis:  an infection involving the soft tissue surrounding the eye, which presents with diffuse (rather than focal) edema and erythema.  Preseptal cellulitis does not cause isolated tenderness over the lacrimal sac, distinguishing it from dacryocystitis.

Management



The management of dacryocystitis aims to alleviate symptoms, treat the underlying infection, and restore normal tear drainage.  Treatments include the following:



  • Warm compresses and gentle nasolacrimal duct massage promote tear drainage (
    figure 2
    ).
  • Systemic antibiotics control bacterial infection; oral antibiotics are typically adequate, but IV administration may be necessary in severe cases.
  • Nasolacrimal duct probing or irrigation relieves obstruction (if needed, it is performed by an ophthalmologist).
  • Surgical intervention (dacryocystorhinostomy) is indicated for persistent or recurrent cases.
  • Predisposing factors such as chronic rhinosinusitis are addressed.

Prognosis



The prognosis for dacryocystitis is generally favorable.  Most cases respond well to conservative measures.  However, extension of localized infection may cause complications such as preseptal cellulitis, orbital cellulitis (infection of the orbital fat and extraocular muscles), or orbital abscess.

Summary



Dacryocystitis (

image 5
) is an inflammatory condition of the lacrimal sac caused by obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct.  Presenting symptoms include erythema, swelling, and tenderness over the lacrimal sac in the medial canthus region of the eye.  Dacryocystitis is often managed conservatively with warm compresses, massage, and antibiotics, but surgery may be required to alleviate chronic or persistent obstructions.
